ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lectures and virtual seminars
Problem solving section with instructor
Recorded lecture, online live study hall and live Q&A and problem sections.
We had recorded lectures and then discussion sections once a week.
combination of virtual seminar and asynchronous lecture.
Recorded and live

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course gives an overview of topics in mechanics and thermodynamics in depth.
Intermediate physics including Lagrangian/Hamiltonian mechanics, central forces, collisions, special relativity, and thermodynamics
A comprehensive overview of classical mechanics, as well as strong introductions to relativity and thermodynamics.
I learned classical mechanics, and a little of thermodynamics at the end of the semester.
I guess some ability to do hard physics problems but not really a replicable skill.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The lectures are well-organized, and the instructor is able to convey core ideas in a super clear way.
The course can be improved if the instructor can publish recordings earlier.
Prof. P is an amazing teacher. The only improvement I could offer is that I think there are better alternatives for the main textbook (Thornton & Marion).

The live sections were definitely a strength. Prof P did a fantastic job clearing up ambiguities from the lecture and working through representative problems. Additionally, I felt the problem sets were hard but not crushingly long. Most were comprised of 5 solid problems and would take me about 8 hours to work through. They were tough to be sure, but more manageable than some Psets I've encountered previously in the department. 

The biggest weakness, for me, were the exams. I came into this class with marginal previous experience in Physics and math (about the bare minimum you could have), so I can't say if my experience is representative of the rest of the class, but for me, the exams were brutal. I appreciated that they were take home and spread out over a multi-day time frame, but they ended up taking me between 10 and 12 hours to complete, which I did at the sacrifice of other courses. It was a ton of problems, which were often significantly harder than anything on our Psets. I found them to be graded fairly, though.

It facilitated high engagement, but the combination of watching lectures asynchronously, meeting for a seminar on extra homework problems, and doing weekly homework assignments was a lot and increased my workload and stress during the pandemic.

Most of the homework problems didn't really help me understand or improve, they were just confusing. Every problem was different and I didn't feel like I gained anything. More PSET help and office hours with TAs are a must, more TAs too.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the recorded lectures are great means for this course. Virtual discussion sections further give me more practices in relevant topics and have a beeter grasp of the knowledge.

The live sections were vital to my understanding in the course. The recorded lectures were tougher, and I got lost frequently and couldn't exactly decipher what was a derivation and what was critical information. They were a good length but definitely were a little harder to follow at times, which is why the Q&A sections were so vital for me.

I really liked the flipped classroom format of this class. I've never been able to work in a small group on physics problems, it's always been in a large lecture hall with an instructor at the front, so I loved being able to discuss questions and concepts, and see how to actually approach solving problems, in a small setting. It felt like I was getting together with a study group each week. I only wish we had more time, to go over more material and discuss more problems.
Recorded lecture was nice but it still doesn't compare to in person

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I recommend this course to non-Physics major students. The course is well-taught with a clear structure, and difficulty is fair.

If you are comfortable with calculus and a bit of differential equations and linear algebra, I would definitely recommend this course. This is easily one of the best classes I have taken at Yale. The difficulty is perfect - not too easy and not too hard, and immensely satisfying.

I'd say yes. Be prepared to really have to work to understand the material though, especially if you took 180/181 instead of the higher-level intro sequences. But Prof P is a good instructor and doesn't give you anything you can't handle.

I would definitely recommend this to another student. This is probably the best physics course I've ever taken. I learned so much and enjoyed watching the lectures. The material is very interesting, even though this is not the first time we've seen these topicsyou look at them from a new perspective and learn different problem-solving techniques.

Not really, it's a hard physics class that didn't make me more confident in my abilities or a lot more knowledgeable. After taking this course I just feel a sense of doom as it is only the beginning of the upper level physics major.
